facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 3 of 1958 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 3 of 1958. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 8, 1956,

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 8, 1956, of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Regular Appeal No. 1 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 8, 1956, of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Regular Appeal No. 1 of 1953. T. Desai and B. P. Maheshwari, for the appellants.

facts.text: Learned Trial Judge decreed the suit in full with costs and future interest by judgment dated September 26, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Trial Judge held that they were, and in that view of the matter decreed the suit in full with costs and future interest, by his judgment and decree dated September 26, 1952.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court allowed the appeal and dismissed the plaintiffs suit by judgment dated October 8, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court of Rajasthan at Jodhpur, by its judgment and decree dated October 8, 1956 allowed the appeal and dismissed the plaintiffs suit. Each party was directed to bear its own costs throughout.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Each party was directed to bear its own costs throughout. The High Court granted the necessary certificate under Art. 133 1  a  of the Constitution. That is how the appeal is before us.

facts.text: Defendant-respondent owed money to the plaintiffs-appellants during course of business as commission agents for the defendant at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: It is only necessary to state the following facts in order to appreciate the question of law that has to be determined in this appeal. The defendant-respondent is said to have owed money to the plaintiffs,

facts.text: Defendant drew two mudatti hundis in favour of the plaintiffs for 35 thousand rupees: one for 20 thousand payable 61 days after date, other for 15 thousand payable 121 days after date.

anchor.surface_text: Towards the payment of those dues, the defendant drew two mudatti hundis in favour of the plaintiffs, for the sum of 35 thousand rupees, one for 20 thousand rupees payable 61 days after date, and the other for 15 thousand rupees payable 121 days after date.

facts.text: Plaintiffs endorsed the two hundis to G. Raghunathmal Bank and asked the Bank to credit their account with the amount on realisation.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs endorsed the two hundis to G. Raghunathmal Bank and asked the Bank to credit their account with the amount on realisation. On the date of their maturity, the Bank presented those hundis to the defendant,

facts.text: On maturity date, Bank presented hundis to defendant, who dishonored them.

anchor.surface_text: On the date of their maturity, the Bank presented those hundis to the defendant, who dishonored them. Thereupon the Bank returned the hundis to the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Bank returned the hundis to the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Bank returned the hundis to the plaintiffs. As the defendant did not pay the amount due under those documents on repeated demands by the plaintiffs,

facts.text: Defendant did not pay amount due under hundis on repeated demands by plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: As the defendant did not pay the amount due under those documents on repeated demands by the plaintiffs, they instituted a suit for realisation of Rs. 39,615, principal with interest.

facts.text: Plaintiffs instituted suit for Rs. 39,615 principal with interest in Court of District Judge, Jodhpur on January 4, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: they instituted a suit for realisation of Rs. 39,615, principal with interest. On those allegations, the suit was instituted in the Court of District Judge, Jodhpur, on January 4, 1949.

facts.text: Defendant admitted execution of the hundis.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to set out the defendants written statement in detail. It is enough to state that the defendant admitted the execution of the hundis, but alleged that they had been drawn for purchasing gold in future

facts.text: Defendant alleged hundis drawn for purchasing gold in future and plaintiffs did not send gold, so hundis not honoured.

anchor.surface_text: but alleged that they had been drawn for purchasing gold in future and since the plaintiffs did not send the gold, the hundis were not honoured or accepted. It was denied that the defendant owed any amount to the plaintiffs

facts.text: Defendant denied owing any amount to plaintiffs or that hundis drawn in payment of debt; contended hundis without consideration.

anchor.surface_text: or that the hundis were drawn in payment of any such debt. It was thus contended that the hundis were without consideration. The most important plea raised by the defendant in bar of the suit was that the hundis were inadmissible

facts.text: Defendant pleaded hundis inadmissible because not stamped according to Stamp Law.

anchor.surface_text: in evidence because they had not been stamped according to the Stamp Law. On those pleadings, a number of issues were joined between the parties, but the only relevant issue was issue No. 2 in these terms-

facts.text: Issue No. 2: Whether the two hundis, unstamped, inadmissible in evidence? Onus on defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the two hundis, the basis of the suit, being unstamped, were inadmissible in evidence?  OD   which perhaps are meant to indicate that the onus was on the defendant in respect of this issue .

facts.text: Defendant led evidence first as onus on him; examined as D.W.5.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the defendant led evidence first, in view of the fact that the onus lay on him. He was examined as D.W.5, and in his examination-in-chief he stated,

facts.text: Defendant as D.W.5 stated he did not receive gold towards hundis, asked to return hundis but not returned, drew Ex. P.1 and P.2 written in Roopchand's hand, no notice to honour.

anchor.surface_text: I did not receive any gold towards, these hundis I asked them to return the hundis, but they did not return them., I had drawn the two hundis marked Ex. P. I and Ex. P. 2. They are written in Roopchands hand. I did not receive any notice to honour these hundis.

facts.text: Hundis referred to as Ex. P.1 and Ex. P.2 throughout evidence recording.

anchor.surface_text: His other witnesses, D.Ws. 1, 2 and 4 were examined and cross-examined with reference to the terms of the hundis and as to who the author of the hundis was. All along during the course of the recording of the evidence

facts.text: Trial Judge held on issue 2: plaintiff paid penalty, documents exhibited under signatures, sec 36 applies, cannot be rejected; decided against defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in this case the plaintiff having paid the penalty, the two documents in suit having been exhibited and not under the signatures of the presiding officer of court and the same having thus been introduced in evidence and also referred to and read in evidence by the defendants learned counsel,

facts.text: Hundis executed in December 1946 when Marwar Stamp Act 1914 in force.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also noticed the fact that when the hundis were executed in December, 1946, the Marwar Stamp Act of 1914 was in force and ss. 9 and 11 of the Marwar Stamp Act, 1914,

facts.text: Suit filed January 1949, stamp duty and penalty paid under Marwar Stamp Act 1914.

anchor.surface_text: It was also noticed that when the suit was filed in January, 1949, stamp duty and penalty were paid in respect of the hundis, acting upon the law, namely, the Marwar Stamp Act, 1914.

facts.text: In 1947 new Marwar Stamp Act came into force amending 1914 Act, similar to Indian Stamp Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also pointed out that the documents appear to have been Admitted in evidence because the Trial court lost sight of the fact that in 1947 a new Stamp Act had come into force in the former State of Marwar,

facts.text: High Court held admission of hundis was pure mistake, could go behind trial court order relying on Ratan Lal v. Dan Das.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon a previous decision of the Rajasthan High Court in Ratan Lal v. Dan Das  1 , the High Court held that as the admission of the documents was pure mistake, the High Court, on appeal, could go behind the orders of the Trial Court

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court misdirected on s.36 Stamp Act; admission cannot be questioned once admitted in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court misdirected itself, in its view of the provisions of s. 36 of the Stamp Act. Section 36 is in these terms- Where an instrument has been admitted in evidence, such admission shall not,

facts.text: Hundis marked as Exs. P.1 and P.2 with endorsement 'Admitted in evidence' signed by Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The record in this case discloses the fact that the hundis were marked as Exs. P. 1 and P. 2 and bore the endorsement admitted in evidence under the signature of the Court.

facts.text: Execution of hundis admitted by executant himself.

anchor.surface_text: those two hundis which had been properly proved- if they required any proof, their execution having been admitted by the executant himself.

holdings.text: The High Court misdirected itself in its view of the provisions of s. 36 of the Stamp Act by holding that it could go behind the trial court's admission of the hundis.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court misdirected itself, in its view of the provisions of s. 36 of the Stamp Act. Section 36 is in these terms- Where an instrument has been admitted in evidence, such admission shall not,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.36 categorically bars questioning admission at any stage; High Court wrongly relied on 'pure mistake' and precedent to revisit trial court's order.

holdings.text: Where an instrument has been admitted in evidence, such admission shall not, except as provided in section 61, be called in question at any stage of the same suit or proceeding on the ground that the instrument has not been duly stamped.

anchor.surface_text: Where an instrument has been admitted in evidence, such admission shall not, except as provided in section 61, be called in question at any stage of the same suit or proceeding on the ground that the instrument has not been duly stamped.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of s.36; categorical language leaves no room for exceptions beyond s.61.

holdings.text: The only exception to s.36 is under s.61, which does not apply to the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The only exception recognised by the section is the class of cases contemplated by s. 61, which is not material to the present controversy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.61 inapplicable as no facts trigger it; s.36 admits no other exceptions.

holdings.text: A question of admissibility on stamping grounds must be decided then and there when the document is tendered; once admitted, even wrongly, the matter is closed for the parties.

anchor.surface_text: That section is categorical in its terms that when a document has once been admitted in evidence, such admission cannot be called in question at any stage of the suit or the proceeding on the ground that the instrument had not been duly stamped. The only exception recognised by the section is the class of cases contemplated by s. 61,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural discipline required by s.36; court must apply mind at tendering stage; parties must object promptly.

holdings.text: Once a document is marked as an exhibit after admission and the trial proceeds on that footing with use by parties, neither the trial court, appellate court, nor revisional court can go behind the admission order, which is not reviewable.

anchor.surface_text: The record in this case discloses the fact that the hundis were marked as Exs. P. 1 and P. 2 and bore the endorsement admitted in evidence under the signature of the Court. It is not, therefore, one of those cases where a document has been inadvertently admitted, without the Court applying its mind to the question of its admissibility. Once a document has been marked as an exhibit in the case and the trial has proceeded all along on the footing that the document was an exhibit in the case and has been used by the parties in examination and cross-examination of their witnesses, s. 36 of the Stamp Act comes into operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show judicial endorsement, reference in evidence, witness exams; admission final and binding on all courts.

holdings.text: The two hundis were properly admitted in evidence and proved, their execution having been admitted by the executant; the High Court erred in refusing to act upon them.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court has erred in law in refusing to act upon those two hundis which had been properly proved- if they required any proof, their execution having been admitted by the executant himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission per s.36 final; execution admitted (f13, f28); resolves admissibility under issue 2.

anchor.surface_text: The record in this case discloses the fact that the hundis were marked as Exs. P. 1 and P. 2 and bore the endorsement admitted in evidence under the signature of the Court. It is not, therefore, one of those cases where a document has been inadvertently admitted, without the Court applying its mind to the question of its admissibility. Once a document has been marked as an exhibit in the case and the trial has proceeded all along on the footing that the document was an exhibit in the case and has been used by the parties in examination and cross-examination of their witnesses, s. 36 of the Stamp Act comes into operation.

In our opinion, the High Court has erred in law in refusing to act upon those two hundis which had been properly proved- if they required any proof, their execution having been admitted by the executant himself.
